awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  In-orbit Satellite Servicing Interface for Science and Commercial Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will affect numerous science and commercial spacecraft. When science satellites with high-value payloads are launched, the satellite capabilities and mission life can often extend well beyond the typical five-year mission life, sometimes operating for more than 10 years. This means that in many cases, the actual mission life of a satellite may be governed by the amount of fuel on board. While the economic benefits of refueling exist for larger commercial satellites (thousands of kilograms), it is not as clear for smaller satellites (hundreds of kilograms and smaller). The proposed project, a refueling system for smaller satellites, can increase the United States’ scientific, military, and commercial capabilities in space. 

The proposed project will remove the complexity of performing spacecraft proximity operations and docking in order to facilitate commercial refueling through a ‘bolt on’ standardized component with the associated sensors and functions. The system will be installed during production on the ground. This integrated package of sensors, communications, fueling valves, and docking latches will provide the functionality required for a servicing vehicle and a client satellite to safely approach, securely dock, and exchange fuel between the two vehicles.  It would be contained within a component named the Integrated Servicing Interface (ISI), simplifying satellite design by standardizing the technologies and interfaces required to facilitate in-orbit refueling capabilities. This proposal will define concept of operations and capture requirements, determine the optimal optical alignment approach for near-field operations and docking, identify the suite of sensors required for each phase of the mission, select the appropriate intersatellite link to ensure robust communications between SC, and implement the design of the ISI by producing a flight-like prototype.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This Phase I Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Program funded by the National Science Foundation (NSF) supports development of a reliable spacecraft rendezvous and docking solution developed by Orbit Fab. This report details the outcomes of the project and provides industry operational context and societal benefits of the technology.

In order to expand commercial, scientific, and government space activities and develop an economy in space, it is necessary to develop an underlying infrastructure that supports sustainable long-term space operations and enables new mission and technology concepts. In-orbit refueling, satellite servicing, construction, inspection, orbital transfer services, and other promising new capabilities are currently being advanced and will form the backbone of the future infrastructure in space. All of these technologies rely on safe and reliable rendezvous, proximity operations, and docking (RPOD). RPOD is the Guidance Navigation and Control (GNC) process by which two spacecraft are able to safely come together and attach in space. Precision formation flying and sample return (e.g. from the moon, mars, or asteroids) are types of scientific missions that rely on these spacecraft capabilities, and which have significant potential to advance scientific understanding of our solar system.

Previous RPOD efforts have largely been focused on large crewed systems, such as on the International Space Station (ISS), with highly capable GNC subsystems and a large mass and volume allocation for docking hardware and RPOD sensors, or have focused on more complex non-cooperative docking with unprepared client spacecraft. These efforts, even those which have sought to implement RPOD on a smaller scale such as NASA's CPOD mission, have also involved significant non-recurring engineering costs as they have focused on developing RPOD systems for their single specific use case. Following the "single mission" development pattern for RPOD limits the widespread adoption of this spacecraft capability, which otherwise has the potential to spur economic growth in the space industry and provide broad positive downstream impacts to businesses and communities on earth. The cost of custom developing RPOD for each use case drives costs to an impractical level for most commercial and scientific users and increases the operational complexity for many systems. Therefore, an off-the-shelf RPOD solution is key to enabling the further development of space infrastructure and to enabling the economic and scientific growth that would benefit from it.

To address this need, Orbit Fab is developing the Smart Proximity operations And Rendezvous Kit (SPARK). SPARK is a one-size-fits-many solution for RPOD enabling two spacecraft to safely dock and operate in close proximity (e.g. for satellite inspection and formation flying). Orbit Fab has recently completed this NSF Phase I Program to conduct an initial study of the feasibility of the SPARK technology. As part of this effort, extensive simulations of a baseline RPOD system were developed. These simulations demonstrated that SPARK will be capable of bringing two spacecraft together with precision alignment, suitable for docking with available docking adapters such as Orbit Fab's Rapidly Attachable Fluid Transfer Interface (RAFTI) Space Coupling Half. Additionally, a prototype of the SPARK system was developed and used to complete a series of laboratory tests and demonstrations showing that SPARK can be implemented using realistic hardware.

This project has advanced knowledge of the requirements of cooperative RPOD systems. Requirements are difficult to confirm because RPOD is a very complex activity due to all the subsystems and operations that need to coordinate, and the severe consequence of potential failures. We were able to validate requirements through a combination of (a) directed discussions with 150 potential users and stakeholders, (b) simulation of the RPOD system performance, and (c) testing the RPOD hardware in a 3DOF environment. This resulted in a robust set of requirements for SPARK that will enable safe proximity operations and are compatible with the docking requirements of Orbit Fab's RAFTI docking interface.

SPARK was successfully advanced to the targeted development level and a roadmap has been identified for full flight qualification of the system. Upon operational verification, SPARK is intended as a commercially available product that is broadly accessible to the marketplace for integration into missions such as commercial satellite servicing, Orbit Fab's in-space refueling, and scientific endeavors.
